instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message:
this came in dead, no power. Found corrosion around thunderbolt port. Cleaned and replaced what was bad and unit now powers on and passes all tests I throw at it. The backlight acts a little funky though. 

Backlight only activates once progress bar starts loading under the Apple logo, not before that. 

Alt-boot, during hardware test and as mentioned the first 5-10 seconds of boot it stays off. Once it kicks in it stays on. 

SMC reset and PRAM reset didnâ€™t fix it. 

Any thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message: Does this have the wrong LCD assembly on it? 2015 models and newer are different and will cause backlight problems like this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message: Can't say for sure, history of the machine is unknown. I have an Early 2013 display, can I use that to test on this Mid 2014?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message: 4924 is a 2015 model! Get a known working 2015 model LCD for testing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message: This is a MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Mid 2014), would a 2013 display work?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Jay, post: 29972"]This is a MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Mid 2014), would a 2013 display work?[/QUOTE]

you will need a late 2013 display. 

early 2013 display use logic board same as 2012
late 2013 display use same logic board as 2014

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message: Thanks, will see if I can get my hands on one of those.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message: Come on guys, the board is a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> so it is a 2015 board!!, not 2012, not 2013, not 2014 but 2015!! So get a known good "2015" LCD assembly to test..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message: I guess they like to ignore my advice and keep messing about....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message: Hope you don't mean me by "they"

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight issue
threads.message: Yeah, this is the exact behavior of a late 2013/2014 screen on a 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. Should be good once you get the right screen on there.
